conclusion: Problem involves a particle moving along two semi-circular arcs with radius 1 meter from point A to point C in 5 seconds.
Need to find average velocity and average speed of the particle.
Two semi-circular arcs with radius 1 meter, starting from point A to point B, then from B to point C.
There's a straight line from A to C.
North and east reference in the diagram.
First semi-circle centered at point B.
Point B is where the two arcs meet.
Semi-circle from A to B and another from B to C, both with radius 1 meter.
Displacement is the straight-line distance from starting point to ending point with direction.
Average velocity is displacement divided by time.
Distance is the actual path length traveled by the particle.
Average speed is distance divided by time.
Displacement from A to C is the straight-line distance.
Label 'x: the displacement of the particle' from A to C as a straight line.
Straight-line distance from A to C should be the diameter of the circle formed by joining the two semi-circles.
Each semi-circle has a radius of 1 meter, so the diameter is 2 meters.
Path from A to B is a semi-circle with length π meters.
Path from B to C is another semi-circle with length π meters.
Total distance traveled, s, is 2π meters.
Displacement from A to C directly is 4 meters east.
Points A, B, and C are aligned horizontally with semi-circles above and below the line.
Horizontal line with points A, B, and C marked, and two semi-circles: one above from A to B and one below from B to C.
Straight-line displacement from A to C is along the horizontal line.
